edu.ncsu.csc.Galant.graph.component

Class Graph

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.ncsu.csc.Galant.graph.component.Graph
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    LayeredGraph

    public class Graph
extends java.lang.Object
    Stores all nodes, edges and related information for use in graph algorithms.
    Author:
    Michael Owoc, Ty Devries (major modifications by Matt Stallmann)

        protected java.util.List<GraphState> states
        To do:
        should handle this in the same way that GraphElementState is handled; perhaps a graph can be another GraphElement with attributes such as a list of nodes, etc.

        Default constructor.
        To do:
        let the Terminate exception propagate all the way to the top, where it can be caught based on whether or not you're running an algorithm

    • Method Detail

      • reset

        public void reset()
        Resets the graph to its original state at the end of an animation.

      • latestState

        public GraphState latestState()
        Returns:
        The last state on the list of states. This is the default for retrieving information about any attribute.

      • getLatestValidState

        public GraphState getLatestValidState(int stateNumber)
        This method is vital for retrieving the most recent information about a graph, where most recent is defined relative to a given time stamp, as defined by forward and backward stepping through the animation.
        Parameters:
        stateNumber - the numerical indicator (timestamp) of a state, usually the current display state
        Returns:
        the latest instance of GraphState that was created before the given time stamp, or null if the element did not exist before the time stamp.
        See Also:
        AlgorithmExecutor

      • numberOfNodes

        public int numberOfNodes()
        Returns:
        the number of Nodes in the current Graph

      • nodeIds

        public int nodeIds()
        Returns:
        the largest id of any node + 1; this should be used when allocating an array of nodes, as there is no longer a guarantee that id's start at 0 and are contiguous.

      • numberOfEdges

        public int numberOfEdges()
        Returns:
        the number of Edges in the current Graph

      • edgeIds

        public int edgeIds()
        Returns:
        the largest id of any edge + 1; this should be used when allocating an array of edges; unlike the case of nodes, it should not really be needed -- edge id's are assigned contiguously; we provide it to avoid confusion.

      • isDirected

        public boolean isDirected()
        Returns:
        true if the graph is directed, false otherwise

      • setDirected

        public void setDirected(boolean directed)
        Parameters:
        directed - true if setting the graph to directed, false if undirected

      • getNodes

        public java.util.List<Node> getNodes()
        Returns:
        all nodes in the graph; this version can only be used when there is no algorithm running; some nodes may not yet exist; inScope() without the 'state' argument only checks to see if a node has been deleted.
        To do:
        Just like the Algorithm provides NodeQueue, etc., it should also provide NodeList as a data structure to avoid the template.

      • getNodes

        public java.util.List<Node> getNodes(int state)
        Returns:
        all nodes in the graph that exist in the given state.

      • getEdge

        public Edge getEdge(Node source,
                    Node target)
             throws GalantException
        Returns:
        an edge with the given source and target if one exists; throws an exception otherwise; if the graph is directed, source and target must match.
        Throws:
        GalantException

      • deleteEdge

        public void deleteEdge(Node source,
                       Node target)
                throws Terminate,
                       GalantException
        Deletes an edge with the given source and target if one exists; throws an exception otherwise; if the graph is directed, source and target must match. This is called only during algorithm execution. Not clear how it would be used since we can hide edges.
        Throws:
        Terminate
        GalantException

        public void deleteNode(Node n)
                throws Terminate
        Deletes (but does not permanently remove) the specified Node from the Graph. Starts a new algorithm step if appropriate

        Terminate

      • addInitialNode

        public Node addInitialNode(java.lang.Integer x,
                           java.lang.Integer y)
        Adds a new Node to the Graph
        Parameters:
        x - the x coordinate of the new node
        y - the y coordinate of the new node
        Returns:
        the added Node; called only during editing

      • addNode

        public Node addNode(java.lang.Integer x,
                    java.lang.Integer y)
             throws Terminate
        Adds a new Node to the Graph
        Parameters:
        x - the x coordinate of the new node
        y - the y coordinate of the new node
        Returns:
        the added Node; called only during algorithm execution; the assumption here is that the algorithm has to "know" the position of the node it is adding. The only difference from the above is that an algorithm step is initiated if appropriate
        Throws:
        Terminate

      • addNode

        public void addNode(Node n)
        Adds a node to the graph during parsing. The node has already been created.

      • addEdge

        public void addEdge(Edge edge,
                    int id)
        Adds a new Edge to the Graph with the specified source and target Node IDs. Note: for undirected Graphs, "source" and "target" are interchangeable.
        Parameters:
        sourceId - the ID of the source Node
        targetId - the ID of the target Node This variant is used during parsing; also does the work of adding the edge to the list of edges and those of its source and target.

      • addEdge

        public Edge addEdge(Node source,
                    Node target)
             throws Terminate
        Adds a new edge to the graph with the specified source and target. Starts an algorithm step if appropriate. Note: for undirected graphs, "source" and "target" are meaningless.
        Returns:
        the added edge This variant is used during algorithm execution if the actual nodes are known.
        Throws:
        Terminate

      • addEdge

        public Edge addEdge(int sourceId,
                    int targetId)
             throws Terminate,
                    GalantException
        Adds a new edge to the graph with the specified source and target. Starts an algorithm step if appropriate. Note: for undirected graphs, "source" and "target" are meaningless.
        Returns:
        the added edge This variant is used during algorithm execution when only the id's are known.
        Throws:
        Terminate
        GalantException

      • addInitialEdge

        public Edge addInitialEdge(Node source,
                           Node target)
        Adds a new edge to the graph with the specified source and target. Note: for undirected graphs, "source" and "target" are meaningless.
        Returns:
        the added edge This variant is used only during editing.

        public void removeEdge(Edge e)
        Removes the specified Edge from the Graph
        Parameters:

                       Node target)

      • numberOfLayers

        public int numberOfLayers()
        Returns:
        the number of layers if this is a layered graph

      • numberOfNodesOnLayer

        public int numberOfNodesOnLayer(int i)
        Returns:
        the number of nodes on layer i

      • smartReposition

        public void smartReposition(java.lang.Double boost)
        Call the repositioning algorithm Currently the only supported algorithm is Force directed repositioning
        Parameters:
        boost - is the extent to which degree of a node will cause it to repel other nodes - repulsive force is multiplied by degree raised to the boost power.
        See Also:
        edu.ncsu.csc.Galant.graph.component.GraphLayout#forceDirected()

      • smartReposition

        public void smartReposition()
        same as smartReposition(boost) but uses the default boost, as built into the force-directed algorithm.

      • undoReposition

        public void undoReposition()
        Restores node positions as they were before the last smartReposition()
        To do:
        maintain an another instance of GraphLayout to do this

      • xmlString

        public java.lang.String xmlString()
        Returns a valid graphml representation of the graph; for use when no algorithm is running

      • xmlString

        public java.lang.String xmlString(int state)
        Returns a valid graphml representation of the graph; for use when you want to export the current state of a running algorithm.
